questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Two weeks ago, he was diagnosed with an ischemic stroke of the right middle cerebral artery. He was treated with thrombolytics and does not have any residual symptoms. His pulse is 82/min and regular. Cardiovascular examination shows no abnormalities. Echocardiography shows a reproducible, transient, low-volume, right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum during coughing. Which of the following conditions is caused by failure of an embryologic process similar to that responsible for this patient's heart condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Midgut volvulus is caused by malrotation of the intestines during fetal development. Malrotation is not the embryologic process responsible for PFO.

B) INCORRECT:

Transposition of the great vessels is caused by a failure of spiraling in the aorticopulmonary septum during heart morphogenesis, resulting in a defect in which the aorta leaves the right ventricle and the pulmonary trunk leaves the left. Failure of spiraling is not the embryologic process responsible for PFO.
Image Description:

I: Development of the muscular interventricular septum and interventricular foramen
- The primary ventricle is a single cavity that is separated from the atrial cavity by the endocardial cushion. Ventricular septation begins with the formation of a muscular interventricular septum, which arises from the floor of the primitive ventricle and grows cranially toward the endocardial cushion. The interventricular foramen is the space between the endocardial cushion and the growing edge of the muscular interventricular septum and it allows for interventricular communication.

II: Development of the aorticopulmonary septum
- The aorticopulmonary septum develops from ridges of tissue derived from neural crest cells within the ventricular outflow tract (truncus arteriosus). These ridges are continuous with the bulbar ridges of the bulbar cordis (not shown here).

III: Development of the membranous interventricular septum and closure of the interventricular foramen
- The membranous interventricular septum develops from the bulbar ridges and the endocardial cushion.
- The caudal end of the aorticopulmonary septum fuses with the muscular interventricular septum and closes the interventricular foramen.

IV: Division of the ventricular outflow tract
- The aorticopulmonary septum fuses and rotates 180Â°, dividing the outflow tract into the aorta (from the left ventricle) and pulmonary trunk (from the right ventricle).

C) INCORRECT:

Hirschsprung disease is caused by failure of neural crest cell migration during intestinal development. Failure of neural crest cell migration also plays a role in some conotruncal cardiac abnormalities, including transposition of the great vessels, tetralogy of Fallot, and persistent truncus arteriosus. However, it is not the embryologic process responsible for PFO.

D) INCORRECT:

Syndactyly is caused by a failure of apoptosis, which normally destroys tissue between the digits during limb development, leaving them unfused and individually mobile. Failure of apoptosis is not the embryologic process responsible for PFO.

E) INCORRECT:

Thyroglossal duct cysts are caused by failure of the thyroglossal duct to obliterate during thyroid development. Failure of obliteration is also the mechanism behind both branchial cleft cyst, in which a branchial cleft persists, and Meckel diverticulum, in which the vitelline duct persists. Failure of obliteration is not the embryologic process responsible for PFO.

F) CORRECT:

Hypospadias is caused by a failure of the urethral folds to fuse, in the same underlying embryologic process responsible for PFO. Other defects caused by failure of fusion include uterus bicornis, in which the paramesonephric ducts fail to fuse, as well as cleft lip and cleft palate, in which the maxillary prominence fails to fuse with the medial nasal prominence. Most patients with PFO do not require treatment. However, sometimes, as was likely the case here, patients develop paradoxical emboli resulting in ischemic stroke.
questions.hint: A transient right-to-left atrial shunt that occurs during coughing, which increases right atrial pressure, confirms that this patient has a patent foramen ovale (PFO). PFO is caused by a failure of the septum primum and septum secundum to fuse after birth.

questions.text: An investigator is studying human genetics and cell division. A molecule is used to inhibit the exchange of genetic material between homologous chromosomes. Which of the following phases of the cell cycle does the molecule target?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The cell membrane pinches in at the equator and divides into two haploid daughter cells during telophase I. No genetic material is exchanged during this phase of the cell cycle. Therefore, the molecule would not target this phase.

B) INCORRECT:

Chromosomes align at the equatorial plane during metaphase II. No genetic material is exchanged during this phase of the cell cycle. Therefore, the molecule would not target this phase.

C) INCORRECT:

Prophase II is part of meiosis II. It is the phase in which chromosomes condense and the spindle apparatus forms. No genetic material is exchanged during this phase of the cell cycle. Therefore, the molecule would not target this phase.

D) CORRECT:

Chromosomes align, pair, and exchange genomic material through homologous recombination during the pachytene stage of prophase I. Therefore, the molecule under investigation must target prophase I in order to inhibit the exchange of genetic material.
Image Description:

During the course of meiosis, four gametes develop from one mother cell.

For the recombination of genetic material, two processes occur in meiosis I. The original mother and father chromosomes are randomly distributed to the daughter cells. During prophase I, a crossing-over of the homologous chromatids occurs (formation of chiasmata), resulting in an exchange of genetic material.

E) INCORRECT:

During anaphase I, homologous chromosome pairs separate via disintegration of the chiasmata. No genetic material is exchanged during this phase of the cell cycle. Therefore, the molecule would not target this phase.
questions.hint: Chromosomes exchange genetic material before the chromatids separate.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl with a recently diagnosed seizure disorder is brought to the physician by her mother for genetic counseling. She has difficulties in school due to a learning disability. Medications include carbamazepine. She is at the 95th percentile for height. Genetic analysis shows that the patient has a 47, XXX karyotype in all cells. An error in which of the following stages of cell division is most likely responsible for this genetic abnormality?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

During prophase I, which is the first phase of meiosis I, homologous two-chromatid chromosomes form a pair and exchange genetic material (crossing over). Errors in this phase can cause chromosomal deletions, duplications, inversions, or translocations but are not typically responsible for aneuploidy.

B) CORRECT:

X chromosomal nondisjunction during maternal anaphase II or anaphase I can generate a 24, XX gamete. Anaphase II is the phase of meiosis II during which a 2c (double-chromatid) chromosome separates at the centromere into two 1c (single-chromatid) chromosomes. Nondisjunction of the X chromosome during anaphase II causes a daughter cell to receive both 1c X chromosomes after meiosis II finishes. Anaphase I is the phase of meiosis I in which the chiasmata disintegrate and two homologous 2c chromosomes separate. Nondisjunction of the X chromosomes during maternal anaphase I causes a daughter cell to receive both 2c X chromosomes after meiosis I finishes. This daughter cell then undergoes meiosis II normally and generates two daughter cells each with two 1c X chromosomes.

Defective paternal anaphase I followed by normal paternal meiosis II can result in a 24, XY gamete but not a 24, XX gamete. A defect in paternal anaphase II can result in a 24, XX gamete but triple X syndrome is typically caused by maternal meiotic defects and only rarely by paternal meiotic defects or postzygotic (mitotic) defects.

Maternal meiosis (oogenesis) begins during the fetal period and is arrested at prophase I until puberty begins. Meiosis resumes during ovulation but is arrested once again at metaphase II until fertilization occurs. Paternal meiosis (spermatogenesis) begins during puberty and takes approx. 2 months to complete.
Image Description:

During the course of meiosis, four gametes develop from one mother cell.

For the recombination of genetic material, two processes occur in meiosis I. The original mother and father chromosomes are randomly distributed to the daughter cells. During prophase I, a crossing-over of the homologous chromatids occurs (formation of chiasmata), resulting in an exchange of genetic material.

C) INCORRECT:

During telophase II, which is the fourth phase of meiosis II, the cell membrane pinches in at the equator and the parent cell divides into two cells. An error in paternal telophase II would generate one completely denucleated sperm and one sperm with double the genetic material (46, XX or 46, XY). Fusion of a 46, XX or 46, XY sperm with a normal 23, X ootid would result in a 69, XXX or 69, XXY zygote (karyotypes of a partial hydatidiform mole). An error in an earlier phase of paternal meiosis II can cause the formation of a 24, XX sperm.

D) INCORRECT:

Metaphase I, in which homologous chromosome pairs align at the equatorial plane, is the third phase of meiosis I. Nondisjunction during paternal meiosis I followed by normal paternal meiosis II can result in a 24, XY sperm but not a 24, XX sperm. Fusion of a 24, XY sperm with a normal 23, X ootid would produce a 47, XXY zygote (karyotype of Klinefelter syndrome). A defect in a specific phase of paternal meiosis II rather than meiosis I can cause the formation of a 24, XX sperm.
questions.hint: Seizure disorder, learning disability, and a 47, XXX karyotype are characteristic of triple X syndrome, a non-inherited aneuploidy. The patient's nonmosaic karyotype indicates a meiotic error. A 47, XXX zygote is formed by the fusion of a hyperploid 24, XX gamete with a normal 23, X gamete.

questions.text: A male newborn is delivered at term to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. The mother has no medical insurance and did not receive prenatal care. Physical examination shows microcephaly and ocular hypotelorism. There is a single nostril, cleft lip, and a solitary central maxillary incisor. An MRI of the head shows a single large ventricle and fused thalami. This patient's condition is most likely caused by abnormal expression of which of the following protein families?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The sonic hedgehog (SHH) protein of the hedgehog protein family plays a critical role during embryonic development and morphogenesis of the central nervous system, craniofacial structures, and limbs. Single gene mutations in the SHH signaling pathway result in malformations such as holoprosencephaly and midfacial defects, as seen here. Holoprosencephaly is also associated with other inherited or acquired conditions such as trisomy 13 and fetal alcohol syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

The transforming growth factor (TGF) protein family plays an essential role in the embryonic development of bone, cartilage, and skeletal muscle. Mutations in the TGF signaling pathway can result in abnormal development of these tissues, impaired wound healing, and various types of cancers. However, holoprosencephaly and midfacial malformations would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Homeobox (HOX) proteins play an essential role in the organization of the embryo in a craniocaudal direction. Mutations in HOX genes typically cause malformations and malpositioning of the developing limbs. However, holoprosencephaly and midfacial malformations would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

The fibroblast growth factor (FGF) protein family is responsible for the lengthening of the developing limbs of the embryo via stimulating mitosis in the mesoderm. FGF gene mutations, therefore, result in hypoplasia/aplasia of the limbs. However, holoprosencephaly and midfacial malformations would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

The Wnt-7 protein of the Wnt protein family plays a role in cellular growth and proliferation at the distal end of the developing limbs as well as in dorsal-ventral patterning during the embryonic development of various structures (e.g., urogenital tract). Mutations in the Wnt signaling pathway may result in limb malformations. However, holoprosencephaly and midfacial malformations would not be expected.
questions.hint: This newborn has alobar holoprosencephaly, which is characterized by a monoventricle and fused basal ganglia. This condition is commonly associated with facial malformations such as a single nostril, cleft lip, or a single incisor, all of which can be caused by a mutation in a gene that is involved in the formation of a midline in the ventral forebrain and maintaining anteroposterior limb polarity.

questions.text: A male newborn delivered at 32 weeks' gestation to a 41-year-old woman dies shortly after birth. The mother did not receive prenatal care and consistently consumed alcohol during her pregnancy. At autopsy, examination shows microcephaly, an eye in the midline, a cleft lip, and a single basal ganglion. Failure of which of the following processes is the most likely cause of this condition?

choices.text: Fusion of the lateral palatine shelves

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Failed fusion of the lateral palatine shelves results in a cleft palate, which was not observed on this newborn's autopsy. Rather, the autopsy showed a cleft lip, which occurs when the medial nasal process fails to fuse with the maxillary process. Furthermore, failed fusion of the lateral palatine shelves would not account for the other anomalies observed.

B) INCORRECT:

Nondisjunction of chromosome 18 leads to trisomy 18, also called Edwards syndrome. Typical features include clenched fists, low-set ears, micrognathia, prominent occiput bone, and rocker-bottom feet, none of which were described in this newborn's autopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Failed closure of the rostral neuropore results in anencephaly, which is characterized by the absence of the forebrain and severe cranial anomalies (e.g., an open calvarium or an encephalocele). Because brain development does not occur, this condition is virtually always incompatible with life. This newborn was born alive and has findings consistent with forebrain development on autopsy (the presence of a basal ganglion and an eye in the midline, both of which originate from the forebrain).

D) INCORRECT:

The 1st branchial arch is the origin of the maxilla, the mandible, the zygomatic bone, and the Meckel cartilage. Other derivatives of this arch include the malleus, the incus, and the sphenomandibular ligament. Errors in the formation of the 1st branchial arch lead to facial abnormalities such as micrognathia, cleft palate, and glossoptosis and/or mandibular hypoplasia, none of which were seen on this newborn's autopsy. Pierre Robin sequence and mandibulofacial dysostosis (Treacher-Collins syndrome) are characterized by first branchial arch misdevelopment.

E) INCORRECT:

Errors in the development of the metencephalon cause malformations of the pons and cerebellum. They are furthermore associated with a spectrum of conditions that manifest with Dandy-Walker malformation, the key features of which are an enlarged fourth ventricle, an aplastic cerebellar vermis, and an enlarged posterior fossa. This newborn's autopsy showed neither malformations of the pons or cerebellum nor Dandy-Walker malformations, but rather severe craniofacial anomalies, which would not be expected with abnormal development of the metencephalon.

F) CORRECT:

Failed forebrain cleavage (i.e., the separation into a left and right hemisphere) leads to holoprosencephaly, which manifests with severe maxillofacial anomalies (e.g., cleft lip, nasal deformities, or cyclopia), a singular basal ganglion, and a singular ventricle (monoventricle), most of which can be seen on this newborn's autopsy. The separation of the two hemispheres usually occurs during the fifth or sixth week of pregnancy; failure to do so most typically results in a first trimester spontaneous abortion, but fetuses occasionally survive to the third trimester, as was the case here. Maternal alcohol consumption is a strong risk factor for holoprosencephaly as well as fetal alcohol syndrome.

Holoprosencephaly is also associated with trisomy 13.
Image Description:

MRI head (FLAIR weighted; axial plane) of a 12-month-old boy with global developmental delay, irregular sleep patterns, and poor weight gain.

There is incomplete forebrain division, with the cerebral lobes differentiated posteriorly but remaining fused anteriorly. The lateral ventricles are also fused.
questions.hint: This condition has been associated with disruption of the sonic hedgehog signaling pathway.
